course_name: General Earth and Space Sciences II
review: I liked it a lot. Prof. Koschinsky's part is not that hard, but she often lets her PhDs have a lecture or two, which might at times not be as good. Prof. Unnithan is not really passionate about this part (-though on Helgoland and more advanced courses he is really good-), so you might get bored there. Prof. Thomsen's part is - of course - amazing and not that hard either. Non-SES Physics-haters might not enjoy that class that much because Prof. Vogt's part can get relatively hard. However, his slides are just incredibly good - he should write a textbook, really - and he is always willing to answer all kinds of questions and to re-explain things. All in all, a must for anyone also even slightly interested in Geosciences.

review: Really nice! I personally loved the geological aspect of the excursion most - the cool thing is that you get to see a side of the island that is normally inaccessible (so you should really take the one-time chance to join that trip) and get to learn lots. It's not that hard either, but you will probably really have to work together in your groups to be sure that you got everything, because Prof. Unnithan is at times not that organized in his lectures.
an okay-elective. Prof. Nugent is just amazing and Prof. Meyer-Ortmanns... well... better not expect too much... and save some of your readings for the lecture-time ... ^^
any comments?\r\n

People need to relaaaaaaaaaaaax! really prof. Lattemann is a great guy and he is super chill about  everything. hes one of the most honest and down to earth professors I know! also he tries very hard to make stuff fun . the assignments and interactive learning through the simulations were really nice.

people just like to bitch a lot.

It's a nice class. You don't need to read the books, the slides and assignments will do for the exam.
This course sucks, don't take it. Just kidding...
It's incredibly boring, especially that the professor seems to think he and his class are fun! Never can concentrate in his class due to his problematic way of speaking English.

How boring can a class really be? Come to this class and you'll find out. Also, the criteria for comment presentation is very unclear and it takes a lot of time to talk to the professor to get things straightened out.

course_name: General Biochemistry and Cell Biology II
review: Great course, the workload is doable, solving open questions in groups and discussing the answers is highly advised.\r\n
I failed this course, retake ftw!!
Very nice course but interestingly quite useless in the practical CS world. The professor is really good though but I think the TAs sometimes mess up the tutorials.
As easy as ABC ...

course_name: Advanced Computer Science Lab Course II (Software Engineering Lab)
review: If don't get good partners, you are screwed!!
useless course, its a pity for CS majors that they can't graduate without passing this course.
easyy

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences II: Helgoland Excursion
review:
Amazing course... I took it as a home-school elective. As someone who is not ESS/IES, I was a bit concerned that the academic aspect of the course will end up being a too bland and boring for my taste. Not true at all. There was lots to learn. Especially stuff about geology. Marine biology, on the other hand, felt a bit forced. I didn't see the connection between the two, and maybe there was none. But that should have been emphasized. What you basically learn is dynamics of earth (stratigraphy etc) and pieces of marine life on Helgoland.  

Also, there is this:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ge-kB4NcMdU

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences II: Helgoland Excursion
review: A really great course for anyone who would be interested in going to Helgoland and seeing it from a geological point of view. In my opinion, most people would enjoy this excursion, not just IES/ESS students! The marine biology part could have been a bit better integrated, but all-in-all the excursion was a fantastic way to learn about marine biology and geology outside of the classroom and is essential for anyone interested in similar subjects. Though the days can be a bit long and the projects a bit chaotic, everyone manages to have a lot of fun and the professors definitely do their best to make the work worthwhile!

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences II: Helgoland Excursion
review: Probably one of the best excursions. Not only is it a lot of fun but you also get a firsthand knowledge about geology and marine biology that is only possible to get in the field. Lots of hand on stuff, ranging from the figuring out the stratigraphy of rocks and their composition to learning about different marine organisms and their adaptations. Also working in groups on the reports as well as cooking together makes for an unforgettable bonding experience

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences II: Helgoland Excursion
review: Really nice course. It's fun and provides you with a hands-on experience with geology and marine biology. Although my major has nothing to do with this course and I thought I might get bored, this excursion was definitely worth it.

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences II: Helgoland Excursion
review: I feel that the excursion was a great experience for everyone involved. It was a lot of fun and definitely hard work, and the chance to get field training in my first year at Jacobs was amazing. That everyone in ESS and IES got to grow as a team was just an added bonus to this excursion. Professors Rossi and Unnithan made this excursion a much better experience than I expected and I thank them so much for doing such a great job on the excursion!

course_name: Advanced Computer Science I (Formal Languages and Logic)
review:
I took this course with Prof. Herbert Jaeger, two years ago. He will offer it again this year. 
The course overall provides a great introduction to theoretical computer science. It introduces the building blocks of computation and what does it mean to run a program. It is a prerequisite for Computability and Complexity, which goes into more detail of those topics. Be sure to understand the difference between infinities before taking the CC course. 
This course is more mathematical and it is NOT a programming course. Though, the math involved is not very complicated. 
The workload is small. You get easy homework each week, and you can find and reference solutions from the web.
Overall, I had a nice experience with the course. Jaeger is one of those professors who always tries to make his course better in all aspects. 
If you want to take it as home school, this would be the perfect option if you are math inclined.

course_name: Fundamental Electrical Engineering I (Signals and Systems)
review: He is teaching at Jacobs in Fall Semesters and at Rice University in Spring. In fall semester, he might just take a flight all of a sudden and fly back to the US. He doesn't have any time for students- neither he is interested in them. I think for courses like this the university should select professors who are more available to students than the professors like Antoulas. ECE would be much more attractive at Jacobs without him.
Best course, best professor ever!
This class is BS

course_name: General Information and Communication Technology I
review: Worst "professor" I have ever seen. He is mostly 10-15 minutes late, never prepared for class, his homework assignments and exams are taken from random websites on the internet, homework is sometimes not even related to the course, and if you ask him a question about it he sends you to the TA. I could list many more things.. this guy is just incredibly bad and not organized at all. \r\n\r\nThe sad thing is that the course content is actually interesting, but you kind of have to teach it to yourself.

course_name: General Information and Communication Technology II
review: Just a very bad professor in general, and he makes the course content be very boring. Unless you are forced to take this class, don't take it.

Möllering is one of the best professors I've ever had. He tries to make the classes very interactive and listens to your questions and concerns. He implements interesting things such as excursions, Marktkauf managers as a guest, and strategic games in his course. 

The course content however is really easy and therefore tends to be boring. But it is in general a pretty easy course. 
The research project he introduced his year was definitely too much work for 25% of the grade though.

The new professor is not any better. He's pretty boring, and doesn't seem to have a lot of teaching experience. I get the feeling that everyone gets the same grades in this class and that he doesn't really look at the assignments you turn it. I asked for feedback and got just some general bullshit. \r\nHowever, if you go to the lectures and actually manage to listen to his boring teaching style, you might learn something, since a lot of the content is very interesting and useful to know for further business classes.

This guy is crazy. The assignments are incredibly difficult, especially for those who don't take ESM 1B, but rather ESM 1A, and have to take this class. \r\nEven though he is not a bad professor, he already expects you to know a lot of stuff and often forgets to explain the basics. \r\nHowever, if you go to his office to ask for advice or hints for a certain homework problem, he is more than willing to help you.

The course seemed to be fun in the beginning, but it got more and more boring, and the professors seemed to be less and less organized and prepared as time passed. The course content does not make a lot of sense since the lectures don't build up on each other, and it is in general difficult to listen to them for two hours straight. \r\nI would not recommend this USC.

course_name: Introduction to Information Management and Systems
review: I really enjoyed the course. The content is very interesting, and the case studies you have to do and present are actually a lot of fun. However, there are way too many readings that you have to do and I never managed to do them all. The unfortunate part is that a part of the final exam is based on these readings. \r\nThe course is also very interactive and great for these people who like to discuss a lot and share their ideas.

Challenging course. Nice for developing your thinking skills and exercising your think muscle. Course could've been more broad and included ideas on different programming paradigms. Overall, Challenging but important course.

The world's worst teacher award goes to...Henkel. The worst professor I have seen in my life. He does not give any cracks about teaching. When asked, he refuses to give algebraic examples (in my opinion he cannot come up with one). He can cover a whole book in a lecture by only saying "this is easy so I skip."

course_name: Advanced Electrical Engineering Lab Course II (Electronics Lab)
review: There are some professors who make you feel nothing but shit. Knipp is good with doing it.

The course is indeed easy and it has the tendency to get boring. More should be done in class in terms of grade. Having a 70% final exam is scary.\r\n\r\nI found the research project to be actually proportional to the weight it has in terms of grade.
One of the best instructors on campus. His only aim in classes is to teach unlike professors who just read out stuff in order to cover the topics for the exam.

This class is horribly designed. It is very easy to get lost. The professor is obviously passionate about his subject but he does not seem to be able to get students interested at all. \r\n\r\nStill waiting to see how he grades. Haven't  heard good things about grading.

The course was not hard but there was a lot of workload. Professor Latteman seemed to improvize all the time giving the idea he did not really have a clear idea of what he wanted to teach. \r\n\r\n35% of the grade depends on how good your team members (with which you write the case studies) are. I think this should change.
Dittrich is a professor one can learn a lot from if bothered to pay attention. He does challenge one's ability to pay attention though.

course_name: Academic skills in a nutshell: an introduction to writing an academic paper
review: The class is useful only to those who have never written a referenced paper before. \r\n\r\nI do like the fact it is integrated with another course though. For me it was integrated with Society and Economy and I thought it helped me in terms of deadline. I had a polished version to submit for Society and Economy.
Maubach is a character. The fact that many non-science related majors take the course forces him to lack rigorousness. \r\n\r\nGood grading scheme.

course_name: General Earth and Space Sciences II
review: It's an amazing class with amazing Profs. All four of them really know their stuff and could talk about it for hours; mostly even without boring their students. I guess especially Vogt and Thomsen should be pointed out, Vogt for his extremely clear and useful slides and Thomsen for his general teaching style. \r\nEven of you're not interested in geosciences at all, this class will make you be interested and gives you a nice general knowledge!
Wonderful course, absolutely essential knowledge for math students. Very experienced teacher with engaging teaching style.

course_name: Seminar in Algebra, Lie Theory and Geometry
review: It's absolutely enjoyable to sit with experts and learn from their comments. Great place to give talks and learn things that are not emphasized in the books.

Having many students from India and Pakistan the course was enriched with a great deal of local knowledge. \r\n\r\nDiscussions were vivid and interesting. The guest speakers should be chosen more carefully.

This course it worth its 7.5 credits. You homeworks are part of the grade and are not negligible (but doable). \r\nHowever, if you do them, you will gain a lot of experience with general problem solving, and will understand the course material much better. In the end, they are also a means to test if Mathematics is really your cup of tea. \r\nThe instructor was really great and made the lectures always a fun event. By all means, attend his lectures!

The course is worth its 7.5 credits; the homework is not negligible (but doable). 
On the other hand, doing the homework will make you understand the material fully and is a good preparation to the midterm and final exams. 
The general topic is interesting. The fact that you work in multi-dimensional space makes things harder than Analysis I, but now you are prepared to do it. 
The professor is good and teaches the stuff well.

This is definitely the most fun course I took this semester. A great concept for math classes, a small group and a terrific instructor come together. 
This course really gave me feedback on my presentation skills and give insights into interesting mathematical topics I would probably otherwise never hear about. 
The instructor is one of best at Jacobs, in a course made for him. A must!
Nice prof, course is a bit tricky
Not as theoretical as GENCS I, very interesting nonetheless.

I really like the course concept. The topics discussed are always interesting and often something you probably not hear of otherwise. Having to give presentations is also good. \r\nThis course is cannot compare to the breathtaking Spring 2014 edition, but still is definitely worthwhile.
The workload is appropriate for its 7.5 credits, i.e. totally not negligible, but you can manage. And solving the homework is actually good for you.

Unfortunately, this semester the course was not taught well: The instructor was often unprepared and didn't structure the class well. A systematic building up of a theory did not happen; hence not really allowing to obtain a better overview of the subject.

After Linear Algebra I, this course was taught was better. It was more structured, the materials used were significantly easier to understand without sacrificing rigour. \r\nStill, the bigger picture did not always come across, and there were moments when I felt lost. May be due to the partially quite abstract topic (tensor products!) though.
A great and interesting course taught by a great professor giving always fun lectures. Great choice for your transdiscplinary.
I don't like the teaching style, but would be a fantastic course if someone like Kohlhase or Schonwalder taught it.

+ Awesome course
+ Love the content
+ Love the Professor
- Ridiculously difficult quizzes
- Some assignments are really messed up

course_name: Advanced Biochemistry and Molecular Biology II
review: This course can be tough as nails and really tests how eager you are to study biochemical pathways. Very fun, challenging and interesting though.
The course is not terribly difficult but the lectures are not very structured and thus a pain to study.\r\n
Really good course, here Nugent shows his full potential as a lecturer - don't be fooled by his performance in General Inorganic.\r\nThe course is nicely paced and generally really nice to follow.

course_name: USC - Chemistry and Psychology of Food
review: The course is - as expected for a USC that is offered for the first time - a tad bit unorganized but does have the potential to be offered yearly.

Again a course that could potentially be nice but since half of the course is on  cancer only and as unstructured as cell bio (also has the nickname cell bio III) the course is not amongst my favorites. Illenberger's part is very nice and structured though.\r\n

Content-wise this course is really interesting as an introduction to Computer Architecture. I would recommend this as a home school elective for people who are really interested in learning the fundamentals of Computer Science. If you don't want to go into that much detail, then take the less advanced, General Information and Communication Technology, but in my opinion this course is much better, because It covers all the basics. Dr. Stamerjohanns was one of the most competent CS professors here, but unfortunately he's not teaching here anymore.

Very important course for CS students, but wouldn't recommend it as an elective (unless you are really interested in CS and already have some background) . Class attendance is very important, as Prof. Schoenwaelder teaches very well. As most of Schoenwaelder's classes, it takes some effort, but it's very rewarding in the end. Think twice before skipping a class, but if you do go through it, in the end you'll really feel that you understand more about how computers work.

Absolutely amazing. The course is very nice for people who like abstract problems. One of the most interesting CS classes. The professor is one of the very best we have here at Jacobs, he is competent, reasonable, and he makes the class interesting and gives you the opportunity to play with the homework as much as you feel like it. You can also immediately see his passion about the content. Don't underestimate it though: This course will be very easy if you are into theoretical CS and abstract problems (time flies when you study about this course) but do not take it as an elective JUST because the overall workload seems to be so low.

course_name: Advanced Computer Science I (Formal Languages and Logic)
review: Very interesting course for people who want to have a good introduction into theoretical computer science. Might become boring or overwhelming if you're not interested into the topics though.

The course is easy, and understandable. It also covers enough to make me satisfied. I didn't have any prior knowledge on differential equations, and I feel like I have learned a lot by taking the course, while also having very easy homework. The professor has very good teaching style, he walks you through everything, only expects you to solve problems that prove that you've understood the course material. He does NOT challenge you with problems that are unnecessarily complicated, or the kind that take ages just because of annoying computation complexity and ugly numbers. Take it without thinking twice.

course_name: Fundamental Computer Science I (Algorithms and Data Structures)
review: If you are a CS student, take this course as seriously as possible. Getting a good grade is not as important as really learning the subject. The content of this course will be the main focus of your internship and job applications and it is important that you understand it well. Last year the course was slightly easier than what it should be (in my opinion), so if you feel that it's going slow, ask the professor for extra problems. I remember him gathering some interview questions from 3rd year students last year.

course_name: General Mathematics and Computational Science I
review: Interesting course, lots of material, appropriate workload. One thing I didn't like was that the lectures just scratched the surface of some topic and immediately jumped into another completely different area.
I have only 1 thing to say that might apply to everyone: Doing a good job in the proposal will make your life sooo much easier during the thesis.
Probably one of the best introductory courses Jacobs has to offer. The course really 'rewires' your brain into thinking as a computer scientist. And SML was GREAT ;). \r\n

The most interesting course of the 4th semester of CS. Time really flew by during those 75 minutes. The assignments were quite fun to solve and think about. Definitely recommend for people who are into theoretical computer science.
I think the course is mis-titled, should be more like 'Anatomy of the Human Eye and Ear.' The professors monotone method of lecturing makes it difficult to gain knowledge in class.

course_name: Statistical Methods I: Exploring Relationships and Comparing Groups
review: The Professor is a terrible educator. What Professor Boehnke confusingly explains in 175 minutes of class equates to what I and  several classmates learn in 20 minutes from looking at the slides and using Google. I and many other never go to that class for this reason.
Awesome French teacher, highly recommendable! :)
Useless class, waste of time.
Nothing interesting taught, just memorizing and no practical application whatsoever.
Great course with a great professor. Wouldn't change it if I could.

PMPP is one of only two first-year IPH classes that is actually about politics, and a great class at that. The Professor is very knowledgeable and this is definitely reflected in his teaching. What we learn in this class is not only very applicable and useful knowledge, but it is also taught to us in a way that makes us retain this knowledge, unlike with most classes. Professor Ney's style of lots of class participation and getting students to teach each other by means of long presentations is enjoyable and an effective teaching technique. This class and professor remind me of why I wanted to study IPH originally and have been a big reason for me not leaving Jacobs.

Definitely the most useful class I've taken at Jacobs. This course should be taken by anyone looking to found or expand social ventures, businesses, or almost any kind of institution in their lifetime. We learn how to approach problems and situations as entrepreneurs in ways that create the greatest outcomes and benefits. The Professor's teaching style and wide-ranging knowledge could not be better suited for this class. This class is an inspiration to myself and others to be entrepreneurs in the future.

Professor is enthusiastic and knowledgable, very good at moderating discussions. Content of the class is applicable/useful in all kinds of contexts. Readings are well-chosen + interesting. Grading very reasonable.

Teaching style (not too engaging, same format each lectures) makes it hard to follow class content. Class topic and readings in itself are interesting, but could be taught/communicated in a much more lively way.

course_name: Statistical Methods I: Exploring Relationships and Comparing Groups
review: Partly disagree with previous comment -  in my view, the Professor is very good at putting the lecture content into a social science context, encouraging students to think like researchers, and to not just operate SPSS, but truly understand data / numbers. If you just want to grasp the very basics, his lectures are indeed (unnecessarily) lengthy, but for those who want to gain a deeper understanding, Boehnke makes a very good professor. Georgi also very helpful and friendly.

course_name: USC - Health - An Integrative Perspective on Body, Brain and Psychology
review: I gained little from this class (in terms of learning outcome) and although the professors are friendly, the grading scheme of the class and their teaching style definitely require modification. Not sure if I would recommend it to anyone.
Disorganised and nonsensical. The quintessential crap USC course you have to take for the extra credit.
you get to learn from one of the best mathematicians. I took this course because Schleicher was teaching, and I was extremely happy in the end, to say the least.

The class and content is very much focused on anatomy and physiology and the teaching method could use some improvement. There are always too many slides and the professor should try and explain concepts better.

Here's a tip, either go to class, or read the book, never do both. If you go to class, you'll get a good grade on the exam and know just about nothing accurate about finance. If you read the book, you'll do shit on the exam and know just as much as you should have learned in this course, were it taught well. Do both, and you'll come to class confident and leave more confused than ever. Not the best course...has a lot to ask for and lacks organisation and professionalism.

This is a very interesting class but there are a couple of things that can improve. The requirements of the course portfolio are very vague and therefore it's hard to get it right. The method of grading participation in every class makes the discussion a joke because everyone just wants to say something. This is something that HAS to change moving forward. Generally the Professor is ok.

I took this course this semester,and even though it might seem hard, it is not. Cramming four days before the mid-term was enough to get a 1.33. The course is a very fundamental introduction to the unified theory of Magnetism and Electricity. Prof.Materny takes the optics part which is simple enough at the beginning but gets tricky later on. The only mathematical knowledge for this course is a basic knowledge of differentiation and integration. The E and M part gets harder towards the end when he teaches motional EMF. But consistent studying helps. The workload is not much.Just a homework set every week. It is a good course to take as a home school. Gen Physics 1-A is a requisite though.
Great class and an ever better instructor. She needs a bit more confidence when teaching though, otherwise I enjoyed this class.

course_name: Lab Course in Experimental Psychology I
review: Not so bad class. I would recommend anyone looking for easy credits to take this one.

course_name: Dynamics of Literature II: 19th to 21st Century
review: Class started off a drag but the quality of instruction and discussions improved drastically. Keep this one around.

course_name: Dynamics of Literature I: Traditional Models
review: You will actually get lost in the works you cover for this class, which is a good thing.

course_name: USC - Perspectives on Creativity in Nature, Art, and Society
review: Considering this is a USC, there is too much emphasis on the art section of the class. That needs to be addressed.
Fun and interactive class.

course_name: Statistical Methods I: Exploring Relationships and Comparing Groups
review: Boehnke tries hard to make the class interesting but most times he misses the mark. In terms of explaining stuff he's ok but the exam format is ridiculous.

course_name: Academic skills in a nutshell: an introduction to writing an academic paper
review: The citation style section of the class is the only useful part of this class. Otherwise it is a complete waste of time.
The class has been somewhat well organized. Not a bore at all.

The class was ok. I had it this time with Dennis and he's a nice guy, but he can't explain things in an interesting way. It was boring, although the readings tend to be more interesting than the lectures. If you read carefully, you'll do fine.

course_name: USC - Chemistry and Psychology of Food
review: Don't take this. It's horrible.

Schoemann is likeable, clear, and knows his subject well.  The course material is interesting but listening to all the student presentations gets pretty repetitive, most of the readings are far too long, and assignments tend to be a bit confusing.

course_name: General Information and Communication Technology II
review: This class is so bad! The instructor plagiarizes every single word on his slides,hw, quizzes, exams etc. He does not teach anything...

course_name: USC - Chemistry and Psychology of Food
review: For us (2014 spring) it was quite unorganized with the way they settled things with the presentations/exams/quizzes. Personally, it was a lot of theory than practical studies in the psychology area.
I liked the course very much and I think I learnt a lot. Dennis K\u00fcster was really nice and I think we got all the information. The readings are also really good and informative!
This year the professor was awful. The class consisted of boring reiterations of the readings, although they were mostly informative. However, not much input otherwise. Sad.
I love the prof! She is very approachable and the new concept of reading papers and discussing them in groups in class was really interesting and helped me learn.

Prof. M\u00f6llering is one of the best at this university. He really does try to make every class interesting, and you can see that he takes a genuine interest in the students' development. He is a wonderful instructor. I would recommend everyone to take his courses (though I personally preferred his other course, Organization, content-wise).

I haven't taken this particular course, but I HAVE taken a USC (Creativity) with this particular professor. My words of advice: run ... run away (Simba), and never return. \r\n\r\nShe was boring and so was the topic of art. But maybe you're into these things. Probably not though.
A competent Professor who makes difficult subject easy.
Too much irrelevant information and poor teaching.
Some of the worst instructors. Also, quite badly structured course.
Outstanding Professor
Great Teacher with Practical Knowledge

The essence of this course is the discussion. Its good to learn the theories by discussing them with peer students. Professor Cohrs is a very nice person. But the requirement of the course portfolio needs to be clarified further.

The theories covered are interesting and helpful. The professor looks chill at first sight, but actually she is nice and professional. This course requires much knowledge of maths and deep interest in psychology. Otherwise it will be tough and boring.
LOVE Oswald! Crazy class!
Although having few previous knowledge of calculus, I enjoyed the class. Things were thoroughly explained.
Dittrich is knowledgeable and nice, open to questions. Unfortunately, he isn't very interesting to listen to. I like that I could write a small essay every week on a topic to get an overall grade.

Dr. De Santis is one of the most dedicated professors at this university. She is always available to answer student's questions about the course material or statistical methods in general. She really cares about whether students understand the material and is very good at explaining concepts. Of all methods classes, the ones De Santis teaches are always the most comprehensible and enjoyable ones.
One of the more interesting courses in the ISS curriculum in semester 2, at least topic-wise. Sch\u00f6mann is likeable, yet likes to embrace chaos in almost everything he does...

Generally, the topics were interesting but too much focus was on the professor's own research topic (fish). Grading seems rather arbitrary. However, the professor used the same slides for two different courses that should have dealt with very different topics.

course_name: Academic skills in a nutshell: an introduction to writing an academic paper
review: They should limit it to "Academic Writing I: Learn how to cite properly", then it would make much, much more sense. Instead: English for lower secondary school. Ain't nobody got time for that!

course_name: Academic skills in a nutshell: an introduction to writing an academic paper
review: They should limit it to "Academic Writing I: Learn how to cite properly", then it would make much, much more sense. Instead: English for lower secondary school. Ain't nobody got time for that!

course_name: Lab Course in Experimental Psychology II
review: A fun course, great to explore your research interests. The professor is very helpful in choosing the right paradigms and procedures. Count on needing good SPSS skills though and having to spend a lot of time testing people.

K\u00fcster is not as engaging as Kappas. The class is still very interesting and uses an integrative teaching style (lots of discussions, fun videos etc.). Readings were a bit too long  though but if you keep up with them you'll learn a lot.

Good teaching style with group discussions. It helped learning how to grasp the core messages of papers and how to criticize them properly. The professor is very nice and relaxed and knows a lot about this topic.
Interesting topics, nice teaching style. The slides are great with very helpful annotations so that the readings are not essential to understand the class.

course_name: General Biochemistry and Cell Biology I
review: The course is quite demanding but the professor is very enthusiastic and easy to follow. The slides are very helpful.

course_name: USC - Adapt! - A Lifespan Perspective on Successful Aging
review: For a science major this class will be much easier. I liked the general concepts but the teaching style could be better. If you're choosing USCs to avoid science, then don't take this class.

course_name: Statistical Methods I: Exploring Relationships and Comparing Groups
review: No matter how much I studied for Boehnke's exam part, it still was terrible. He tries hard but it's very difficult to follow him. In my opinion, he is not a good teacher.\r\nWhen De Santis was teaching the practical part I enjoyed that a lot. She was great at explaining. It was easy to follow and to comprehend. I hope she will be teaching the practical part in the future again. She is really great.

course_name: Statistical Methods II: Classification, Modelling and Prediction
review: Even though these are more advanced tests, De Santis makes it possible to understand them very well. Always enthusiastic about statistics, it is very refreshing to have a teacher like her. She is very approachable and likes to help out students with their stats questions. Her exams might be challenging but if you go to all sessions for the practical part, you'll do fine.

Most challenging class I ever took (even more so than any BCCB classes I had). However, if you do the readings and exercises you will learn a lot in this class. I generally found it very interesting but at times became frustrated with the amount of work I had to put in.

course_name: General Biochemistry and Cell Biology II
review: Very helpful course. A lot of work but interesting. Open questions and tutorials were very helpful in understanding the materials.
The course was alright, although I enjoyed BCCB II much more. A lot of it was repetition from that class. Poster sessions and designs were very helpful but the exam was very tough.

Bergholz can be summed up in 4 words ''Good grandfather-bad teacher''. Dont be fooled by the innocent pictures of his solar panals and vehicles. He WILL WASTE your time by putting your brain into very mild aspects of Gen EE2 like circuit analysis and will cause you to build an easy image of the exam. Now the TAs make the exams and its open season so you better well be damn prepared unless its gonna go very bad
Him and Antoulas are the best professors in the EE department. If the uni could only get other profs with same teaching styles we would be at the top :)

The course is rather too theoretical, but interesting at times. Unfortunately, the homeworks are more about proving theorems or formulas than applying them, so doing them doesn't really give you clear insights about how wireless works, at least not to me.

course_name: General Biochemistry and Cell Biology II
review: Wonderful course. Definitely my most meaningful class this semester. \r\n\r\nIt is a bit demotivating not to get good grades, compared to people from other courses who get better grades for lesser work, but I would rather have every class be equally difficult than have this one lower its standard.
The course has no structure. Half of the slides are unhelpful and disorganised. Definitely regret taking this course.
I am happy i passed it.\r\n\r\np.s. passing this course is an achievement
bc, lun prof.

This class is one of the very few that actually covers the subject on a truly global scale - comparing media systems on all continents! No continent is left out and the professor is very passionate and nice and we usually had very interesting class discussions as well!

I enjoyed this class very much! The discussions were very interesting and the reading load very managable. Bogaards also did a good job and was in my opinion much better to get along with than in my freshman year in CPS - I guess he just doesn't like teaching lectures.
a lot to learn by heart

In my opinion, the material of this lecture was already discussed in many other classes such as cross-cultural organization and culture and cognition. Most of the material is just repeating it, but with unnecessary exercises and discussions that do not conclude in something worthy.\r\nAlso, the class has too many components, with two different types of presentation and a paper and a report to write. Too many things to do for people that have thesis. It's really unnecessary to have so many components.\r\nDr. Hanke is interesting and she clearly puts a lot of work to make this class more interesting and entertaining. However, this will not be achieved by adding more things to do. We are clustered as it is already...
Most interesting class in Social Psychology!\r\n

The professor has a tendency to skip many lectures and to use questions in the exam where he mentioned the answers very briefly in class (I guess to check whether people actually attend). His slides are not very well structured and he only includes few topics in the class. Also, topics are not explained well. If you want to learn about neuroscience, take the "Systems Neuroscience" class. It's much better structured and pretty much covers the same topics but with more background information.
The instructor had different grating criteria when I took this course so it was rather confusing. I did not enjoy the topics either. It does not have to do a lot with neuroscience.
Not very well structured, no interesting topics, grading of the lab reports is ridiculous.

The professor is not very good at explaining and it doesn't seem like he cares whether a lot of people fail his class. The TA was also not very useful for helping explaining the concepts. At least in the end grading schemes were adjusted.
Great course! We did a lot of interactive stuff not just lectures all day.
Prof. Kuehnen's passion for his discipline is contagious. This course was an inspiration for me and many of my classmates, one of the most interesting courses I have taken.
Great for both psychologists and non-psychologists! Easy explanations and interesting studies. Perfect (social) psychology 101 course!

course_name: Lab Course in Experimental Psychology I
review: I took this course in my first year and it was a great way to APPLY the theoretical knowledge from Empirical Research and Stats. Taught me a lot.\r\nProf. Yan is not the most gifted lecturer, but she took the time to help us with our projects.
Great professor, great course! The discussion proposal are a bit tedious but they teach you a lot.

When I took this course the first time it was offered (2012), half the class was first year GEM students and the other half third year IRB or ISCP students... the mixture wasn't ideal. It would be great if it didn't try to cater to the needs of two different levels and groups.
I learned SO MUCH in this class! Great lecturer, great structure, great projects!!
Really helpful! Lara Christianson is such a nice, helpful lady.

course_name: The Logic of Comparative Research - Case Studies
review: Prof. Schreier is a very talented lecturer, she explains concepts really well. Always enjoyed her classes.

Prof. Ludes has a terrible teaching style... boring and monotonous. \r\nHis grading is arbitrary and based on personal preferences. If you don't tell him what he wants to hear, he downgrades. Not good to raising critical academics... a thorough disappointment.
One of the most motivated professors! She puts a lot of effort into making the class enjoyable and confronting students with recent events and topics. Loved it.
Prof. Bogaards is a little biased and doesn't really like anyone contradicting him and his views. Also, he downgrades you in the paper if you don't cite him... ego much?

The topics are very interesting and the professor has a very nice teaching style. It doesn't go into too much depth, so I recommend it even as an elective. It analyzes the topics in enough detail to help you understand the principles, it also covers some details, but doesn't dive too deep into technicalities, so you won't get confused even if you don't have a lot of background.\r\n

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit Earth and Space Sciences I: Harz Excursion
review: Great excursion! Taking notes during the day and talking about them in the evening really helped understand everything (the professors helped a lot!). Making the report due before the excursion took off pressure during the excursion. Really great if you took GenESS I or GenES I. Amazing!
Great class, am enjoying it very much.
Useful stuff, even if you only take away definitions from it. I would recommend it for first year acm finance students. ( take it before the derivatives lab)
Lars is not the most interesting guy to listen too, but his slides are quite nice, and you can learn most stuff from them. Get the previous quizzes ASAP, they help a lot.

course_name: Reductionism in Physics and its Relation to Philosophy (TDC)
review: Some interesting material, but is presented in a very dull lecture style way. Has mandatory attendance and participation grade but just a typical lecture.

The profs are rather dull at times. Some interesting content such as daisyworld model. Not quite as useful as derivatives lab. Not well structured, deadlines are unclear and almost always have been given extensions.

The workload is challenging, however after you do the homework by yourself you really start understanding the material. The learning curve is steep throughout the whole course, however the professor has his ways of making the course interesting. Make sure you know at least the basic problem solving techniques(induction) and how to define the natural numbers to start with.

course_name: Advanced Physics B II (Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics)
review: Kleinekathoefer is actually a very nice and helpful guy. The homework can be pretty demanding at some points, but the exams are quite easy (since you're not allowed a cheatsheet). Overall a pretty nice course

course_name: Reductionism in Physics and its Relation to Philosophy (TDC)
review: HMO clearly loves hearing herself talk, even though she is extremely boring. The slides have way too much text and formulas on them (which are anyway irrelevant for the exams, but they are still there). Nevertheless, the topics are extremely interesting, just presented in a boring way. You're better off by not going to the course and just reading the slides on your own, it's way more interesting.
I can only agree with the first comment. Furthermore, his feedback on the two essays is very useful and really helped me to improve my writing skills.

The course is very interesting and I think for ISS as well as IPH and other SHSS students very useful. There were two things I didn't like: 1. the reading work load was just way too much  and 2. we focused too much on the American Civil Rights Movement. But we also touched upon various other movements and certainly got a profound theoretical basis.
quite a lot of overlap with BCCB I
Very important class for IPH although I don't like IR theory that much. But it's a necessary evil...\r\nVerweij did a good job!

Unfortunately, this course doesn't just focus on one region but on one country - China. While I feel like I know almost any detail about China, I still feel like I lack even very basic historical knowledge about the other countries in Eas Asia...
Absolutely great course! If it's offered next year - take it! You're gonna get a lot out of this course, not like in other USCs
The workload is less and easier than GenCS  I, and the topics are much more enjoyable :)

course_name: Fundamental Computer Science I (Algorithms and Data Structures)
review: The level of the course is a bit too easy for CS students, imo. There is more theory than expected, however, it is balanced together with some good coding homework assignments, but definitely not enough for a good CS major. Nevertheless, the professor (Pathak) is awesome, he takes (and even approaches  the students himself) feedback throughout the course and applies it asap :)

Simply one of the best CS courses here! 
Notes:
- go to classes, as going through the slides is not enough to get a good grade
- start doing the hw early
- before quizzes always go through the old ones and the respective sections in the old finals, you'll be amazed how much the material overlaps and how easy the quizzes will look :)

Karina is the best! She teaches her classes well and structured and cares if her students understand.\r\nHowever: Meta-analysis is nothing for people who are looking for an easy elective or course to finish up the methods courses. It's important to know stats and have the ambition to complete more assignments than for most other courses (midterm, presentation, one shorter paper, one longer paper).

Professor Diederich definitely knows what she is talking about, additionally she makes sure that the workload is not too high. If you are interested in psychology and some (mathematical) models: Take it, you'll love it!

The new concept (few lectures, then group discussions about papers) is very enjoyable and helps to understand the field very well. Plus, Prof. Olk is amazingly nice and relaxed. She makes sure that people understand, find it interesting, and the workload stays manageable.

course_name: USC - Chemistry and Psychology of Food
review: If you are looking for something easy to slide through and don't learn anything, this course is pretty perfect. BUT: be prepared for a lot of confusion with assignments etc.\r\nIf you are, however, expecting something from which you can actually learn something about psychology of food: no, then this is not for you. Mostly we learnt how to avoid eating unhealthy stuff by making a plan to eat an apple. Sad.
The professor is so full of himself... He wants you to do bad in this class. Completely useless and a waste of time for the CS people. If you have the option - avoid any courses with Baumann.

The only relevant ESM class for computer scientists. Topics are interesting and the professor as well, however, having the final without a cheat sheet for all those numerical methods is plain ridiculous.
Rafael is funny and tries really hard. Still, the course is not particularly interesting or engaging. So only recommended if you are really keen on improving your Spanisch skills.

Without a doubt, the best course I've ever taken at Jacobs. This semester (Spring 2014) we were only two students taking it, and I will never understand why. If you are one of the many who liked the GenCS material on the first year, then you'll definitely love this one. What I loved about it:
1. I got to really understand the theory behind parsing natural language and really see how logics are related to natural language processing. 
2. I got to think about some very interesting problems and brain teasers,
3. This is the kind of stuff prof. Kohlhase is really excited about, so if you liked his performance in GenCS, you'll love it in ComSem.
4. Since prof. Kohlhase could relate the material to his research, we got the chance to be exposed to problems no one else is dealing with. Although, of course, we could only contribute a certain amount, the fact that we got exposed to such interesting ideas was extremely rewarding.  Just take it, it will definitely be a rewarding experience and there's no doubt you will learn a lot.

--- What did you value most about this course?
The course material was interesting. I loved the applications of the material taught in this course. We had a nice equilibrium of theory and practice in the lecture material. I liked that we got a not that rigorous background to some nice concepts of Numerical methods.
Even though I hated working each week for the quizzes, they kept me up to date with the material in the course. 

--- What would you like to see improved about this course?
First: - please improve the slides. There are plenty of tools to write nice presentations (like latex). Please change the font of the text in the slides. Comic Sans is one of the worst fonts ever created. 
- The homework load was too heavy. It did not evaluate the material taught in class. They were about proving random statements that did not help us in any way to learn or understand better the material taught in class. Please revise the homework before giving it to the students. Compared to all other ESM courses offered in the last semesters, this had the worst homework experience. Plenty of homework assignments were not even possible to do without a prior knowledge in numerical software like matlab or octave. Which leads me to the next point. 
- This course may be very well complemented with the matlab lab from the math NatSciLab of GenMath. We could very well have assignments in matlab to implement some specific algorithm. If this method cannot be implemented, at least give brief descriptions of the tools that we can use. Most of the students taking this course are computer scientist. That means that most of the students would be excited about the idea of implementing an algorithm on the computer instead of doing endless calculations on paper. Please consider this. 
- Some background knowledge about concepts wouldn't hurt. Just saying. We would be more interested if we learn that some algorithm is the state of the art in some graphics problem.

The professor was enthusiastic about the material taught. He always presented background information about the subject and he was asking interesting questions. \r\nThe homework problems were interesting. They tested the understanding of our knowledge of the course material but also involved creating nice tools to do different Operating system problems. \r\nThe only thing that I disliked about this course are the slides. The course was not well documented in the course slides and some of the slides did not contain all the information handled in class.
posters were very good, but the content seemed a bit unstructured at times and there was quite a bit of repetition
really interesting course, especially with guest speakers form outside and the practical applications, but the Prof seemed a little unreliable
awesome introduction and perfect other school elective

There was a deliberate effort of professor Baumann to create interesting slides and interesting material for the student, 5 years ago. Since then nothing changed. Only links started to become invalid and most of the the website is with broken links. 

--- What would you like to see improved about this course?
- Organize the course material in such a way that it has a logical flow. Create slides that are more explanatory and give a better understanding of the material taught. 
- This course right now is about memorizing terms that are presented in the slides (with red) until the quiz and the midterm and final. The questions were there just to test the memorizing techniques of the student. The question themselves never gave an intuitive feeling of important concepts of Software Engineering. It were just terms that were presented without any helpful meaning. 
- Maybe try to analyze different products from start to end. In those kind of courses, like software engineering, it would be better to provide case studies than present the theoretical part of an idea.

course_name: Advanced Computer Science Lab Course II (Software Engineering Lab)
review:
Working in teams for this course was interesting. I was lucky enough to have nice partners so I can't complain about this. The idea of the course is interesting. 
I actually had the opportunity to make some friends and see how other people work on projects.

--- What would you like to see improved about this course?
More thinking should be invested to make the good environment for this course. The pair programming in this course is an excellent idea. But this pair programming is well run if both of the participants are on the same level. We did this in the Software Engineering course(This lab should be its implementation). During our first programming assignment we were paired explicitly to not be of the same level so that we will be "fair" for everyone. But that defeated the initial goal of this pair programming. 
The problem is that the course is way to big for everyone to have a nice experience. The course should adapt in such a way it provides the best experience for everyone. Such that in the case there are too many people in the course another method of software engineering is applied like the waterfall model or another agile method.

This is one of the courses that any CS student should master.\r\nThough, I wouldn't recommend it to students who want to take it as a transdisciplinary. It would be better to take the python course instead.

Easy course but take it seriously. This is one of the courses that any CS student should master.\r\nThough, I wouldn't recommend it to students who want to take it as a transdisciplinary. It would be better to take the python course instead.

Mind blowing course. As a CS student I had great challenges to understand completely what is discussed here, but the little I understood was very interesting.\r\n\r\nIf you really like math, take it, but be prepared to devote a lot of time to understand things properly.

Really comprehensive and effective lab course. One of the best few weeks spent in labs at Jaocbs. Mathias Klein is a very good instructor, and makes sure that everyone understands the course well. He also encourages questions beyond the course and is very approachable. Grading is quite fair and appropriate. One of the best courses in Biotechnology!

*Highly* recommended if you like programming with practical applications!

The workload might appear a bit too much at times, but it's definitely worth it.
The instructor (Prof. Kleinekathoefer) is very nice and approachable. In the end you will feel like you actually learned something.
The physics component is minimal (basic understanding) and the programming language is up to the student.

course_name: Advanced Biochemistry and Molecular Biology II
review: This course is a lot of work while taking it. As it focuses on biochemical pathways, I blieve it is one of the most essential courses taught within BCCB. The most important thing this course taught me is not the specific sequences of complicated biochemical pathways, but the ability to see common patterns within these pathways. Once this is understood, this can be applied to different problems and is very helpful. Despite the large workload, the course is very interesting and fun.
You get the chance to do a lot of interesting projects.
Very interesting topic, but lack of structure due to lack of professors in this subject area. Good class for those that hate biochem
Take this class if you actually enjoy thermodynamics or it's a requirement. Sitting through the class for anything else would be a nightmare
Boring lectures, but Vogt knows his stuff and is passionate about it, so you get a bit more excited too
Terrible structure; homework has nothing to do with lectures, and exams have nothing to do with lectures or homework. DO NOT take unless you have some prior biochemistry/BCCB background
Not a fun professor. Don't take unless you have to, or you enjoy having professors belittle you
Easy class, but lacking specialized professors. Good for inorganic chemists, but BCCB should stay away. It won't help you and you'll just complain the whole time
Confusing class, especially since the prof doesn't help very much. Easy 1.0 though

Very nice professor. The topics are interesting(a bit more mathy than most CS courses, but still) and the grading scheme is fair. Not too difficult as a course although mastering the topics requires a lot of additional work

The professor is very very good at explaining(although he really overdoes it often - DAMN YOU BACTERIA POPULATION!!). The homework doesn't require much work and the topics are easy to understand even without any prior knowledge of differential equations. Recommended if you are interested in math even the least bit and want to learn more applied topics.

Overall an acceptable class. By any means the best communication class of ISS, which admittedly is not hard given that the other classes are taught by Prof. Ludes. However, her grading of presentations is very, very particular. We got point deductions for the weirdest, most irrelevant layout-aspects, most of which we were not even responsible for in the first place. The most important opinion to her is her own. Keep that in mind.
Many and very messy proofs. Prof. often overcomplicated simple concepts.
One of the best professors you'll ever meet - if you get to know her a little better. She's so packed-up with knowledge, it might be frightening. Study hard - it's worth it!

Very nice course with moderate workload and difficulty. In this class, professor Lerchl goes a little more in depth than in his first year classes (obviously). BCCB students should maybe already take it in their 2nd year.
The course was really great I am very grateful that we were pushed to practice our presentation skills and the poster was really fun to make.

course_name: Methods and Research Strategies in BCCB
review: This course was incredibly helpful, but also a lot of work. For the 5 credits it was a lot more in terms of assignments (presentation and project proposal and exam) than for other courses
Nice, chilled course with a good instructor. \r\nIdeal if you don't have/take a lot of time for practicing your language skills, but still want to continue learning it.

Very demanding course without a doubt. If you have some programming background, understanding of recursion and logical thinking you won't have much of a problem with it. However, learning curve is steep, and I mean STEEP! The course is designed so it separates the people who really want to do computer science, from those who don't really know what's happening. Solving old quizzes helps a lot, as well as starting your homework well in advance :)

The course has some good ideas and concepts being presented, however, the means of grading don't really test your knowledge. All you need for a good grade is your homework assignments (codes) printed during exams. It is ridiculous amount of writing Java code by hand.

Several times I encountered something I already knew, but in a new light, with a proper understanding of it. Really nice feeling. \r\nUnfortunately, the course also showed me that I need to take maany specialisation courses for understanding all the topics only treated superficially, especially with more involved maths ...

course_name: Natural Science Lab Unit - Numerical Software
review: In general, the workload is REALLY appropriate. Don't underestimate the homeworks!!\r\nApart from that, the instructor unfortunately has a quite pronounced accent. Hence, for me studying on my own made more sense that attending the lectures.

Looking simply at the description, the course appeared to not provide much new stuff. In practice, there were always new details to discover. Also, the Cialdini book used was really nice to read. \r\nThe instructor is not perfect, but often he brought up another aspect which I found helpful and interesting.

Definitely one of the better classes in the IPH major. The first half of the class at times feels a bit theory-heavy (working through Robert Dahl's "Democracy and Its Critics"), but just when you start to tire of it, it changes and you encounter a lot more empirical/pratically-oriented material. The class discussions were consistently on a pretty high level, and the student presentations were of a better quality than I have experienced in most other classes.\r\n\r\nAs for the grading, Bogaards is a quite a tough grader, but ultimately fair. Just don't expect him to do you any favours (he picks up on tiny things that other professors might give you a pass for, like sloppy referencing in PowerPoints and such), and assume that the amount of actual effort you put in will be directly reflected in your grade, i.e. if you do your presentation the night before, he will notice, and you will get a mediocre grade.
P.S By @415 I mean "take it as a specialization course / grad course", not "take it as an elective". The course does require serious commitment and several things are not immediately intuitive.

course_name: Fundamental Electrical Engineering I (Signals and Systems)
review: He comes off as discriminating a lot of times. It's weird really considering he teaches in the US as well (more like mainly); which is a big problem because he makes it very obvious that his priority is Rice. As mentioned before he does not care about his students, doesn't make time for them and is selfish in general in terms of scheduling.
Hard to keep awake at the lectures; takes a very interesting subject and makes a snore out of it. Could be a nice guy but is not really helpful towards out of major people.
He's helpful but I think is very misguided in terms of the level of the students. I mean, if wanted to be treated like a Master's student I would do a Master's on a topic I already learned about...

He is not comparable to Antoulas for he actually gives a shit about his students. Very good lecturing style since he's always ready for questions and needs only a board and some chalk to make you learn. And if you didn't learn, he'll definitely respond to your cries of help. Ends up repeating the lecture every single time when people have questions after class. Such a cutie.

This class is bad only because the lecturer and the TA's seem to assume we have nothing else to study for. I mean, final with no cheat sheet when there are 25 sets of slides? Looking forward to fail it.
No matter whether on your research poster or presentation slides, all that counts here is design, formating and formalities. Don't bother with the content for too long.

Her lectures are entertaining, with lots of youtube videos and stuff. However, as a result, the theory that is actually taught in this course could fit in one single lecture. If you don't care for the laughs and entertainment the professor provides, going to this class is a waste of your time.

While teaching style and class set up are somewhat controversial, Prof. Ludes at least is someone who really knows his stuff. He has read all the relevant literature and personally discussed them with the respective authors. On most issues I fundamentally disagree with him for political reasons, but argueing with someone as well versed as him is fun at least.

The critical discussions are clearly the best part of this course. Prof. Delhey is great at moderating them and contributing his own criticisms of the readings. The biggest weakness of this course got to be the biased choice of literature. The meritocratic, functionalist view on inequality, that is necessarily always part of the discussion, because it is the mainstream criticized by all the other papers is never actually formally introduced by any reading. If it was, discussions in this course could be even better.

If you have taken Stats2, this course will not be very difficult for you. In fact, taken aside the interface of a new software, there is hardly anything new for you to learn. This course should go further and in more detail. The lab sessions are not used very productively at the moment and could be utilized for that.
No readings assigned so one just *bullshits*\r\nabout the essay and the final. The professor teaches by himself but regularly invites guest lecturers --> very mixed quality of these.

course_name: Introduction to Chinese Language and Culture
review: One has to be committed and study for it each week but the progress is impressive! You can actually read and write some Chinese characters and sentences at the end!

As a specialization course, it's really interesting. Things we do are advanced and current. You learn many cool algorithm that are directly applicable for producing amazing results.\r\nOn the flip side, course involves a lot of proofs, which sometimes can really uninteresting to look at.

Great class! Good foundations of business and all concepts related to further studies in GEM or any of the other related majors. Very wonderful class; I enjoyed it and thought it did a good job of providing a comprehensive outlook.

A lot of reading-based work, but other than that - a very interesting topic and course with a great teacher. The presentation style of teaching is very interesting and I feel that the professor thoroughly encourages discussion and interaction between students.

The professor is nice and all - but I think he really messed up with the assessed lab this semester. It was just really a disaster, and the TA's were also confused the whole way through. The rescale was also not as 'generous' as advertised and really frustrated many of us. It just didn't seem appropriate whatsoever that only a few people got outstanding marks while the rest did horribly; also, it's not entirely fair that the make up exam was the same as the regular one. (People with med excuses just re-did the test.) Also, the slides are terrible to study and understand - they are very messy and illogical. I've had to research externally and try to understand concepts myself, and I don't think that I should have to do that for some of the more simple terms or ideas in statistics. All in all, the lectures were not in line or useful to the homework assignments or the tutorials either, and it's just a very poorly structured course. 

Some possible recommendations: Better and more condensed slides that explain the concepts simply. More charts that compare different tests and distinctly highlight the similarities and differences/when to use which. 
Assessed lab that reflects or somewhat follows the pattern of how a homework was given, rather than something very random with concepts that were barely taught in tutorials.

It's not hard to make statistics understandable or interesting; I just feel that some professors don't take the time to step back and think about how to teach their students in the most efficiently and clear way possible.

Again, the professor is wonderful and very nice - it's just the course that I didn't particularly find great.

Wonderful professor - very engaging and tries to make every and each class interesting and comprehensive for his students. Really encourages questions and activities as well. I've enjoyed a wonderful year of B1.2 with Carsten Tiel, and I'm very satisfied with his teaching in this German class. The class is also good at covering enough grammar that it furthers your German skills, but doesn't swamp you with too much grammar.

Good and interesting class if you pay attention and do the readings; I made the mistake of not being caught up on the readings, which made the classes very hard and boring. The professor is strict but he is very passionate about the topics and knows exactly what he's talking about. He's also kind of funny. \r\nWe'll see how the final exam goes, but all in all - it has, so far, been a challenging but interesting course.
One of the best professors ever, he knows his stuff well and knows to explain clearly. Also funny examples with ducks.
Prepare yourself. This professor is a bad ass.  Knows stuff but he's gonna kick your ass with this course.

course_name: Reductionism in Physics and its Relation to Philosophy (TDC)
review: Don't take this course just because you like philosophy or physics or both.  You will be extremely disappointed by how boring the classes can be. Maybe just to fill some credits.
It's easy basically, even though it's more advanced than the lab on the first semester. The final exam can be quite tricky, don't underestimate this course.

Very well organized, you get a solid foundation in the basics of the most simple electronic components.  Don't take it if you're not an EE major, this shit ain't easy. Lab reports are A PAIN and the final exam is quite difficult.

Very nice professor, knows his stuff well and gives examples from the real world.  The theory gets quickly quite abstract/mathematical unlike genEE I.\r\nThe very bad thing this year is that most of the TAs are retarded. They literally RUINED the whole course, also causing so many people to drop genEE on the first semester. But hopefully the professor will only hire smart TAs next years.\r\n
Nice course, good choice if you're a CS major. You can get to learn about some music theory and you have to create an interesting project.
It is a good course overall. It would be better if weekly quizzes were introduced to ensure that students go over the material regularly.

Great and super nice professor. Course was interesting, and we had a lot of readings in which there were 'surprise' pop quizzes. Most times, the professor would hint that there would be a quiz, which was a wonderful thing for him to do. You also have to write an essay at the end, which isn't that hard and the topic is more or less up to you. And there's also a book report and presentation on an assigned chapter and an assigned partner; can be difficult or easy, depending on the partner and chapter you get. All in all, a nice class.

Great course and great professor. He tries to incorporate both practicality and theoretical into the course, which is very nice. D-Thinking is very interesting and really 'forces' you to not only work with your team efficiently, but to achieve a lot of results in a specific time frame.

Unfortunately, the professor can't hold the student's interest at all (apart from 2-3 students). Which is sad as the topic itself  actually is very important and interesting. And apparently the final has been very difficult in the past years.
Enjoyed it. He teaches it really well. Final was difficult though.

Very nice course with inspiring professor. I didn't like the final exam format at all. It was 30 true false questions. You still fail if you get 15 and then each point after that takes your grade up to 0.33. Very risky final.

course_name: Advanced Computer Science Lab Course II (Software Engineering Lab)
review: Very nice simulation of how things work in industry. I advise you to do your part of the work to be fair to other friends. If you become lazy, things will come back to you.
Easy 1.0

Very important course for the career ahead. It familiarizes you with terms and practices of the industry. You'll thank the Prof. once you start working in a company. Though memorization is involved, I feel the negative comments are highly exaggerated.
Amazing course, giving solid theoretical foundation on the topics and very interesting projects and homeworks - face recognition, camera calibration, image hybrids and more

I beg to differ. Once I didn't understand how to solve a problem from his homeworks he kindly invited me to his office after class. I guess you have to show interest and that you've done your homework before coming to him. \r\nI don't blame him for not being more available to undergrad, he only teaches one course in the undergrad program.
A weird thing that I learnt this semester. The professor who are bad at teaching give you the best letters of recommendation. Judge by yourself who this profs are.
I failed in my first year (I had no programing background whatsoever), but when you get used to programming afterwards, it's a complete piece of cake.

course_name: RF and Microwave Component and System Design
review:
Literally, the only explicit circuit design course taught at Jacobs. Really good, Peik is those profs. who will focus 90% on practical stuff for the exam.

There should be a part 2 of this course, one semester is not enough. 

We barely covered everything about matching circuit with lumped elements, trans. lines and microstrips and amplifier design. There's a lot more to RF than that.

course_name: RF and Microwave Component and System Design Laboratory
review: Very useful, you learn ADS, which is an industry standard for RF circuit design. The lab has some limitations as well, but a Jacobs student cannot really comply since it is the ONLY course where you can claim that you actually designed a circuit and be given 5 credits for it!

Interesting course which touches a wide variety of topics.\r\nStudents are required to read through some scientific papers more or less (!) related to physics and come up with a review of a typically important work in a certain field (e.g. Higgs mechanism, quantum computing and Shor algorithm, cosmic inflation etc). Attendance is mandatory, as each session is a student presentation (hence most of the classes ended earlier than 75minutes), with the occasional additional insights given by Prof. Schupp.

Most basic Physics class at Jacobs, highly recommended to all who need a good home-school elective (since Physics students already have it as mandatory). You learn some general stuff, you're not wasting time, you get a decent grade and you earn some credits.\r\nTopics include general mechanics (up to Bernoulli equation) and thermodynamics (up to the first law).

course_name: Advanced Physics A + B Lab I
review: Physics students will be learning a lot from studying for the experiments and the associated quizzes. Various topics are included and contributes massively at the background physics knowledge, unless you continue to go in more depth in other classes.\r\nNot really recommended to non-Physics majors, due to the large amount of workload, including weekly quizzes (before each experiment, on Monday continued on Tuesday) and weekly lab reports (teams of 2-3).

course_name: Advanced Physics A + B Lab I
review: P.S. Look ahead a bit into how an oscilloscope works and check your electricity wiring skills!

Probably the most enjoyable course in the third semester for many Physics students.
Builds on the general knowledge gained in General Physics I in first semester and extends to more advanced topics which will be useful from then on, such as the oscillation modes, Lagrangian formalism, Hamiltonian formalism etc.
The grades also tend to be good, due to an additional 10% transferred from the final exam to the HW, resulting in a well-balanced grading scheme.

All the midterm % is included into the HW grade which makes the grades go up, however the topics are rather complicated and you should devote a large amount of your effort into deeply understanding the course material if you want to not forget 80% of it during winter break.\r\nThis is mandatory but generally its mechanics counterpart (AdvPhys A I) is preferred among students.

course_name: Advanced Physics B III (Condensed Matter and Solid State Physics)
review: Relatively easy class, grading scheme recently changed to 9 out of 10 best quizzes (weekly, before lecture). Two questions per quiz, one of which is from the previous homework (which can occasionally be turned in for bonus points). Therefore the grade should not be a problem.\r\nThe course material is a pretty general (but useful!) introduction to Solid State Physics, the workload is very low (see above), however changing the instructor from Prof. Heine to Dr. Kettemann makes it not worth attending classes anymore, after sitting the quiz (of course, subject to personal opinion).

This will be the course where you'll learn most of the quantum mechanics you will be using in the future. Very useful, the workload is rather high (due to the innovative aspect of the topics), however you will end up with a very solid understanding of the basics of QM.

course_name: Advanced Physics B II (Thermodynamics and Statistical Physics)
review: Having no cheatsheet can cause some students to panic, even if the necessary formulas are given in the exam.\r\nOther than that, if continues the introduction in thermodynamics given in General Physics I class during the first semester and discusses physics from the statistical point of view. Some of the topics learned here can be extrapolated further into other fields as well.\r\nThe homework is absolutely manageable.

You will be learning a bit of everything and at all scales (from atoms to black holes).\r\nHomework is manageable if you attend classes, as reading the slides does not include what the lecturer is presenting in class.\r\nProf. Heine is extremely nice, don't hesitate to approach him about anything.

course_name: Advanced Physics A + B Lab II
review: Same story: weekly quiz before lab, weekly lab report after.\r\nOral exam with Prof. Materny and Bernd in the end about 2 given experiments and one at your choice.

Something this class seriously lacks is circuitry. Not an EE class, but the basics should still be presented. You will be required to know what a transistor is later on (second year), while you only heard of a resistor.

course_name: Advanced Physics A IV (Particles and Fields)
review: Not having a final is a huge help for the 3rd year students who are concerned with finishing the thesis.

course_name: Advanced Physics B IV ( Semiconductor Devices, Advanced Optics)
review:
Taking Solid State Physics in fall helps a lot. During the first half, Prof. Wagner will present the physics behind pn-junctions, transistors and basic electronic devices (solar cell, LED, etc). The end will include bipolar transistors and FETs.
During the second half, Prof. Materny will discuss advanced optics topics (up to polarization vectors and such).
Grading scheme:
10% (first half) + 10% (second half) for HW
35% midterm (only first half)
45% final (15% first half, 30% second half).
(apparently first half weighs more)

I think @470 is a good review, and I mostly agree with the general idea, but not all of the points are valid in my opinion. For example:

1. "It just didn't seem appropriate whatsoever that only a few people got outstanding marks while the rest did horribly" - This actually is appropriate (depending on what you mean by "horribly". Normally the grades should follow a normal distribution, where most people get a 3.0, only a few get a 1.0 and only a few fail. 

2. "All in all, the lectures were not in line or useful to the homework assignments or the tutorials either, and it's just a very poorly structured course" - I actually thought the slides were alright. You can't really explain statistical methods (including the maths) with slides. For that you would need lecture notes or a book. So I think the slides were about as good as slides can be. If the slides have "charts that compare different tests and distinctly highlight the similarities and differences/when to use which.", I think they would encourage people to learn the material by heart and not really understand why they're doing what they're doing.

I think the course should focus more on explaining statistical concepts and the math behind it so people know what they're doing. 2 years ago, at least, it was relatively easy to get a decent grade without worrying about the math behind the concepts at all, which I think shouldn't be the case.

course_name: Advanced Physics A + B Lab I
review: Wagner is horrible as a quizzer. In the oral exam as soon as he sees you don't know something he will keep asking details about that until you are completely lost. His "Satan" nickname definitely suits him.
Very interesting if you're interested in experimental techniques. Prof. Fritz's nice teaching style will definitely keep you captivated. Definitely recommend as a specialization course.

course_name: NatSciLab Unit Biochemistry and Cell Biology I
review: A great course! It is not easy, but very interesting and helpful in gaining the experience in the laboratory.

course_name: General Biochemistry and Cell Biology I
review: Great course, if you are interested in the chemistry of life.
I found this course very interesting. The Prof. Kuhnert is very experienced in all kinds of chemistry areas, and it is very interesting to listen to his fun facts.
Great course! A lot of people regretted not taking it, so if you are interested in research, definitely take it. It gives a lot of new opportunities.
Great Professor. The course is a little slow for the people who want to learn German in 3 years, but quiet fun, interactive and helpful
It would be a lot more helpful if this course would be held in the evenings
